conclusion: To find the propagation speed of light in water, we can use the principle of refraction of light at the interface between two media with different refractive indices.
The refractive index of water is less than that of air, so light will bend towards the normal when it enters water.
The refractive index of water is typically around 1.33, meaning light travels slower in water compared to air.
The angle of incidence is the angle between the incident ray and the normal to the interface, and in this case, it is given as α.
The angle of refraction is the angle between the refracted ray and the normal to the interface, and in this case, it is α/2.
Using Snell's law, the ratio of the sine of the angle of incidence to the sine of the angle of refraction is equal to the ratio of the refractive indices of the two media: sin(α)/sin(α/2) = 1.33/1.0.
Rearranging the equation gives sin(α/2) = 1.33 × sin(α).
The equation sin(α/2) = sin(α/2) is true, so there is no need to solve for α directly.
The speed of light in water can be calculated using the formula v = C / √(sin²(α/2) + sin²(α/2)).
Substituting values into the formula gives v = C / √(2 sin²(α/2)).
